overview_of_class:
The purpose of this course is to teach students how to use what is known about human learning and thinking to facilitate effective organizational growth and change. This course is the most focused on learning of any LOC course. However, in contrast to a typical cognitive science or cognitive psychology class, most of the material in this course is set in organizational contexts. For example, when discussing judgment and decision making, we use examples from medical practice and policy. Likewise, in discussing the cognition of memory, we will analyze examples from the legal system. Although the primary focus is on learning and cognition, we do set these examples from the legal system. Although the primary focus is on learning and cognition, we do set these examples in organizational context.

This course is relevant for all students in SESP (and beyond). The class will expose you to a variety of methods, including instructional design, modeling, and evaluation of learning outcomes. It will help prepare you to design and evaluate learning programs and learning environments. Thus the course is appropriate for students who might become teachers, consultants, human resource or training managers, etc.
name: Learning and Thinking in Organizations
subject: LOC
